<p align="center">
  <span class="pronunciation">(shi-VAH-li-kah CHAH-vahn)</span>
</p>

<p align="center">
  <img src="images/headshot.jpg" width="60%">
</p>

I’m a Master’s student in Biostatistics at **Columbia University**, specializing in applying statistical methods in
health-related research settings. My work focuses on translating complex **real-world data (RWD)** into actionable insights for precision medicine and healthcare operations.

Currently, I am exploring the intersection of public health and machine learning. Most recently, my team placed as runners-up **(Most Public Health Impact)** at the [PRI Narrative 2 Numbers Hackathon](https://pandemicresponse.columbia.edu/pris-narrative-2-numbers-hackathon-turned-qualitative-insights-into-actionable-ideas/){target="_blank"} for designing a community-driven outbreak detection system using NLP.

Prior to graduate school, I spent four years as a Senior Scientist in the Diagnostics Division at **Roche** working on the [Axelios SBX technology](https://sequencing.roche.com/global/en/article-listing/sequencing-platform-technologies.html){target="_blank"}. I also interned at Philips Emergency Care and Resuscitation contributing to post-market studies for medical devices (like AEDs) and worked as an undergraduate researcher in neural engineering and optogenetics at the [NERD Lab](https://sites.bioe.uw.edu/yazdan-azadeh/) under Dr. Azadeh Yazdan. I earned my B.S. in Bioengineering (Data Science) with Honors from the **University of Washington**.

<div style="text-align: center; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px;">

  </div>

Outside of work, you can find me backpacking, rock climbing, watercolor painting, or solo traveling. And although I'm now on the east coast, I remain a diehard west coast sports fan— go 49ers & Warriors & Dawgs!!
